title: How to build a high-performing growth team
insights: Focus on onboarding and activation as high-impact growth levers—improving these consistently moves the needle more than micro-optimizations
Translate learnings from user research into product improvements that scale, building insights directly into the experience rather than just running isolated experiments
Hire growth specialists only after you've proven the concept; early on, focus on fundamentals like product quality and retention
Cohort retention curves are the true measure of growth health—focus relentlessly on improving them through onboarding and activation
When you've learned something valuable through human testing, codify it into the product so it benefits everyone at scale

title: How to speak more confidently and persuasively
insights: Long-term impact of experiments matters more than short-term lift—run experiments and measure their business impact at 1, 2, and 3 years out
Churn is business-model dependent; don't obsess over absolute churn rate, understand what's healthy for your particular model
Use cohort analysis to find the users most likely to retain; double down on activation and onboarding for that specific user segment
Funnel optimization should be collaborative and trust-based, not a silo function—work closely with product to maintain quality standards
Scale growth by understanding which users are most likely to succeed, then focus acquisition and activation on similar cohorts

title: Unorthodox frameworks for growing your product, career, and impact
insights: Your manager has disproportionate power to affect your career trajectory—if growth is stalled, it's often a manager-fit problem, not a you problem
Learn by watching great operators work, not just by reading or instruction—actively observe how successful people navigate decisions and team dynamics
SEO and partnerships were core to Instagram's early growth—virality and word-of-mouth get the credit, but systematic channels matter more
Deep understanding of your team's needs and passions creates psychological safety, which unlocks better collaboration and idea-sharing
If you want to build world-class products at scale, you must include diverse voices and perspectives—homogeneous teams miss critical insights

title: Why most product managers are unprepared for the demands of a real startup
insights: There's a spectrum of PM types: innovators who generate endless ideas vs. executioners who ship and optimize—balanced teams need both
Unsexy investments (performance, UX, developer velocity) often have outsized impact; build custom metrics and run small tests to prove their value to leadership
Ops is often a sign of process inefficiency—the goal should be software and automation, not scaled headcount for repetitive tasks
Non-scalable hacks unlock scalable strategies: founder-led sales, manual retention campaigns, and scrappy tactics validate before automation
Product-market fit erodes over time; you must continuously find new growth strategies as customers shift and competitors adapt

title: Relentless curiosity, radical accountability, and HubSpot's winning growth formula
insights: Relentless curiosity is the foundational trait for successful growth PMs—obsess over understanding customers qualitatively, not just quantitative metrics
Radical accountability means treating every growth problem as your problem; ownership mentality uncovers opportunities others miss
Activation (first-value realization) should be embedded in the core product experience, not built as a separate onboarding layer
Product-led growth requires deep collaboration between growth and product teams; you can't optimize your way past a poor product experience
Only 20-30% of growth experiments succeed; if you're hitting >40%, you're thinking too small with your hypotheses

title: Succeeding as an introvert, building zero-to-one, and PM'ing your career like a product
insights: Treat your career like a PM treats a product: write specs, define success metrics, plan features (skills), and align on goals
Product-market fit is not a destination but something you must continuously recapture—markets evolve and user needs shift
Build a portfolio of bets: a few big, ambitious projects and many incremental improvements; don't bet everything on one outcome
Zero-to-one products require patience, small focused teams, freedom to fail, and low expectations for immediate impact
Resilience through failure is essential; reframe setbacks as stepping stones and learn actively from every stumble

title: The new AI growth playbook for 2026 | How Lovable hit $200M ARR in one year
insights: Only 30-40% of traditional growth playbooks transfer to AI companies; spend 95% of energy innovating, 5% optimizing, because the category evolves every 3 months
Product-market fit treadmill: you must recapture PMF every 3 months as user expectations and competitive landscape shift in fast-moving categories
Give your product away liberally via freemium to enable word-of-mouth at scale; don't compete on user acquisition if your core product creates network effects
Minimal lovable product (not MVP): build for delight, not just viability; emotional connection drives retention and word-of-mouth
Building in public + employee socials + shipping velocity creates sustainable growth narrative and community moat that compounds

title: An inside look at Deel's unprecedented growth
insights: Great product is the foundation; no growth strategy compensates for a product people don't value and won't keep using
Answer questions where people ask them (Reddit, SEO, communities, Quora) before spending on paid ads—cheap channels work when you solve real problems
Test growth strategies at different budget levels ($0, $10K, $100K) to identify who scales thoughtfully vs. throws money at problems
Early-stage growth team should focus on fundamentals: is the website fast? Can people find it? Only then layer in paid acquisition
Cheap channels compound because answers live forever online—one Reddit answer or blog post serves infinite future users without ongoing cost

title: Building Substack
insights: Economic models based on subscriptions (vs. ads) unlock fundamentally better user experiences because incentives are aligned with user value
Features compound in their impact on growth—one killer feature can eventually drive the vast majority of your growth as it compounds over time
As you scale, growth dynamics shift dramatically; strategies that worked at 1M won't work at 10M; you must evolve your approach
Product-market fit and growth come from finding small groups of people who desperately want what you're building and letting them evangelize
Build products people want to invite others to use; network effects are the most sustainable growth engine

title: Lessons from scaling Ramp
insights: Cap table as growth strategy: get founders and operators as early investors; they become customers and champions who drive word-of-mouth
Growth funnel progression should be: founder-led sales → low-cost marketing (content, community, small events) → PR → paid/brand/SEO
Build a culture of hypothesis-driven, data-informed decision-making with MVP mentality; people should fail fast and iterate quickly
Growth ownership means owning output metrics (revenue, pipeline) not just input metrics; accountability aligns incentives with business success
Repeatable, scalable growth processes matter more than hiring great individual contributors; systems compound more than people

title: How to grow a subscription business
insights: Don't prematurely conclude that a channel doesn't work; most companies haven't given channels enough of a real shot with proper execution
Incrementality testing (turning channels off) is the only true way to measure channel contribution, but requires rigor most companies lack
Activation is the highest-leverage lever in any funnel; getting users to their aha moment faster improves everything downstream
If you have strong network effects or word-of-mouth, lean into virality; if not, focus on direct acquisition first
Subscription businesses need distinct strategies for consumer (focus on retention and engagement) vs. B2B (focus on expansion and upsell)

title: The ultimate guide to Martech
insights: Marketing technology is about managing the systems and data infrastructure that enable growth, not just using point solutions
As you scale past 100-150 people, you need someone dedicated to MarTech because the data and systems complexity explodes
The best MarTech hires manage upward, laterally, and downward well; they need strong influencing skills, not just technical knowledge
Product is part of MarTech—clean up your internal data systems first before optimizing external channels; garbage in, garbage out
Start thinking about a dedicated MarTech person when you notice tool sprawl and inefficiencies in how growth data flows through your systems

title: Why ChatGPT will be the next big growth channel
insights: New distribution platforms emerge every 5-10 years; ChatGPT integration will likely be the next major platform shift for startups to capture
Distribution platform changes are prisoner's dilemmas—if you don't build for the new platform, competitors will, and user expectations will shift regardless
Great product is necessary but not sufficient; the separation between winners and losers is who builds distribution first
Platform incumbents don't want to enable their own disruption, so early-movers on new platforms have outsized advantage
Early-stage companies must focus on one platform and go all-in; late-stage companies should hedge bets across multiple platforms

title: Inside Canva: Coaches not managers, giving away your Legos, and embracing AI
insights: Stay product-obsessed at all scales; the best growth comes from building products people love, not from marketing tactics
Freemium strategy requires solving a real problem for free users; only optimize monetization after proving core value retention
Move slowly and intentionally on major product decisions; collect diverse feedback and design collaboratively, not by decree
Empower teams to build their own solutions rather than centralizing functions; self-service scales better than service-provider models
Enterprise expansion requires building new products for enterprise needs; one-size-fits-all doesn't work as you scale

title: How to scrappily hire for, measure, and unlock growth
insights: Activation through better onboarding is one of the highest-leverage growth opportunities; even small improvements compound massively
You need tested hypotheses for every major growth initiative; if you can't run an experiment, the idea probably isn't worth pursuing
You can test and validate at small scale (30 people) as effectively as large scale (100+ people) if your methodology is rigorous
Retention is the foundation; high retention at small scale beats low retention at large scale every time
Southeast Asian startups prove that with focused execution, you can grow massive consumer companies despite limited budgets

title: How marketplaces win: Liquidity, growth levers, quality, more
insights: For pre-PMF marketplaces, focus obsessively on one side and use hacks for the other; don't try to balance both sides until you prove core value
Ownership and accountability culture in product teams drives better growth outcomes than structure or process alone
Build teams around business outcomes, not features; give teams a slice of the business and clear P&L responsibility
Marketplace unit economics and supplier liquidity are more important than marketing spend in early growth
Network effects take time; focus on depth of engagement on one side first before expanding to new sides

title: Brian Chesky's new playbook
insights: Shift focus from traditional growth channels (paid, marketing) to building the best product and telling people about it
Organize by user outcome, not function; one roadmap across company aligned on shared goals drives better speed and product-market fit
Constant evolution and learning is required; you must always be in a state of becoming, expanding what's possible
Empower teams to solve their own dependencies rather than centralizing functions; reduces bloat and improves speed
Product quality and storytelling compound together; neither alone is sufficient, but combined they drive organic growth

title: Developing a growth model + marketplace growth strategy
insights: Build explicit growth models that map inputs to outputs; these should be core to your strategy docs and how you communicate plans
Focus growth investments on core product levers, not growth-specific features; retention comes from fundamental product improvements
Product decisions matter far more than growth tactics when expanding into new segments or geographies
Pricing strategy is a lever you can optimize, but customer success and product fit come first
Resurrection and reactivation are tempting but lower-priority compared to improving retention of active users

title: Rethinking SEO in the age of AI
insights: SEO is a product strategy question, not a marketing question; product managers should own SEO thinking, not delegating to specialists
Teaching users what's possible with your product is more valuable than keywords; focus content on solving problems, not ranking
Hiring expensive growth advisors can short-cut learning curves vs. hiring junior in-house people who take longer to mature
Product-market fit means people are searching for solutions to problems your product solves; without that, no SEO channel will work
AI is changing SEO fundamentally; adapt by focusing on demonstrating unique value and problem-solving, not keyword optimization

title: How to build a powerful marketing machine
insights: For PLG startups, hire product-focused growth people, not pure marketers; product experimentation matters more than marketing tactics
Separate marketing launch support from product feature evaluation; not all product features should be treated as marketing opportunities
Cross-functional alignment between product and marketing requires clear definitions of whose job includes what
Invest in measuring marketing's true impact on retention and monetization, not just top-of-funnel metrics
Brand and go-to-market strategy should inform product decisions from day one, not be bolted on later

title: Lessons from working with 600+ YC startups
insights: Early founders must be able to build and iterate on their own; don't hire too much infrastructure before you've proven product-market fit
Most growth failures come down to simple issues: bad product-market fit, weak founder determination, or lack of customer courage
Fear of rejection kills early-stage companies; 90% of customers aren't early adopters, but the 10% who are will evangelize relentlessly
Hire people with internal motivation and determination to win; these traits compound better than pedigree or past success
Get customers talking to each other and creating content about your product; community is a free growth machine at early stage

title: Building high-performing teams
insights: High-performing teams combine: clear goals/mission, results orientation, team-first collaboration, ownership mentality, and fun
Develop talent internally over hiring experts; institutional knowledge and context matter more than external credentials
Clarify your point of view on go-to-market early; mixing consumer and B2B without clear strategy causes teams to optimize for wrong metrics
DACI framework (Driver, Accountable, Contributor, Informed) eliminates ambiguity and enables faster decision-making
Engage the whole company in growth thinking; revenue ownership shouldn't be siloed to growth team

title: The power of strategic narrative
insights: Strategic narrative is about defining a movement, not just solving a customer's problem; this alignment drives adoption at scale
Tell a coherent story about why your product exists and why customers need it; narrative creates sense-making and buy-in
Market movements create the conditions for new products to scale; ride movements rather than creating products and then looking for markets
Narrative should be used by product leaders and PMs to align teams around why you're building what you're building
Differentiation through story is more sustainable than feature parity; narrative compounds as more people internalize and share it

title: Unpacking Amazon's unique ways of working
insights: Bar Raiser hiring process improves retention by preventing bad hires; the upfront time investment is small vs. long-term management burden
Document-driven decision-making (like Amazon's 6-pagers) improves clarity and accountability in distributed teams
Customer obsession drives innovation better than competitor focus; ask what would delight customers, not what competitors are doing
Disagree and commit: high-quality decision-making requires debate, but once decided, everyone rows in same direction
High hiring standards compound; hiring below standards creates cascading quality degradation in future hires and culture

title: How to find work you love | Jobs-to-be-Done framework
insights: People don't buy products; they hire products to make progress in their lives—understand the job-to-be-done, not the product features
One product can serve multiple jobs; when you understand the jobs, you can tailor onboarding and product experience to each pathway
Customer research should focus on the progress people are trying to make, not on satisfaction or feature preferences
The same product can unlock growth by turning off irrelevant features for different job-to-be-done segments
Growth accelerates when product becomes genuinely helpful for the specific job customers are trying to accomplish

title: How to build deeper, more robust relationships
insights: Vulnerability and emotional honesty are essential to great leadership; teams perform better when leaders model authenticity
Giving feedback is a learnable skill; most people are terrible at it because they haven't been taught how to do it well
Exceptional relationships drive retention, team performance, and growth; they're not soft skills, they're strategic business drivers
Deep relationships require active listening and genuine curiosity about others' experiences and motivations
Continuous improvement beyond sufficiency is how relationships and teams thrive; push 15% beyond comfort to deepen trust

title: AI Engineering 101
insights: Evaluation frameworks matter more than model selection; focus on defining what 'good' means before agonizing over which model to use
Cost-benefit analysis of AI improvements: optimize for impact on business metrics, not marginal improvements in model accuracy
Data quality and labeling are critical bottlenecks; invest in these before trying to optimize model performance
AI failures can have catastrophic consequences in some domains; understand your risk profile and evaluate rigorously
Focus engineering effort on features that improve real user value, not on staying up-to-date with the latest AI frameworks and tools

title: Lessons from 1,000+ YC startups: Resilience, tar pit ideas, pivoting
insights: Early founders should stay scrappy; hiring senior execs and PMs too early creates overhead before you've proven product-market fit
Customer conversations and physical presence matter more than sophisticated marketing; get out of the building and talk to people face-to-face
Perseverance and resilience separate successful founders from those who give up; most overnight successes took 5+ years of grinding
Solve the hard customer problems first; focus on retention and deep product value before scaling acquisition
Many failure patterns are preventable with discipline: don't scale team or spend too early, stay focused on core value

title: Figma's CEO: Why AI makes design, craft, and quality the new moat for startups
insights: Craft and quality become the moat in AI-native markets; commoditized intelligence requires differentiation through design and experience
Build trust with your team by empowering them to experiment; if it's not fatal, let people try their ideas
Product intuition is a hypothesis generator; combine intuition with data to make better decisions faster
Design and taste are increasingly important as AI commoditizes execution; focus on creating beautiful, delightful experiences
Stay opinionated on design while remaining flexible on strategy; quality compounds and becomes harder to replicate

title: Designing your product development process, hiring your first PM, and getting ahead in your career
insights: Dedicated head of product becomes necessary around 4-5 PM team size; before that, PMs can report to CEO or founders
Fast-pivoting teams with clear product vision attract investor interest and find product-market fit faster
Opportunity doesn't come from linear career progression; build relationships across company and stay informed about emerging needs
Define the problem (what outcome to optimize) before specifying the solution (which feature to build)
Empower teams with clarity on outcomes, not directives on solutions; autonomy drives better product decisions

title: The original growth hacker reveals his secrets
insights: Product-market fit means a percentage of users would be very disappointed if your product went away; measure this explicitly
Focus on super users and their needs; double down on what excites them and cut features they don't use
Don't aggressively grow until you've achieved clear product-market fit; premature scaling wastes money and destroys moat
ICE framework (Impact, Confidence, Ease) helps prioritize growth experiments in a structured way
Freemium as a growth strategy works when your free product delivers real value; use it to find your super users, then monetize them

title: The rituals of great teams
insights: Blue loops (scalable growth mechanisms) are the most valuable; identify the organic, viral, or word-of-mouth loop and optimize it ruthlessly
Activation aha moment should have no friction or cost; embedding monetization in the core sharing/activation experience blocks growth
Rituals create culture and alignment; great teams have explicit ceremonies and norms that reinforce their values
Clarity on decision rights prevents slow decision-making; define who drives, who approves, who contributes, and who's informed for each decision type
Culture is defined by the product you build for your employees; internal tools and processes matter as much as external product

title: The 10 traits of great PMs, AI, and Slack's approach to product
insights: Product-market fit is stacked S-curves; you win one segment, then must find and win the next segment, and the next
PMF with current users doesn't equal PMF with target users; you must recapture fit as you expand markets or segments
Word-of-mouth and customer love are increasingly necessary for scaling big businesses as paid channels saturate
Continuous product-market fit requires systematic processes; don't assume yesterday's PMF guarantees tomorrow's growth
Improve team velocity and energy through clarity of purpose, autonomy in execution, and removing decision friction
